safePlants.name: Pawpaw
safePlants.description: The pawpaw tree has smooth gray bark, but becomes scaly overtime. Pawpaws grow in clusters that resemble bananas, are high in vitamin C and healthy fats, and can be eaten raw.
safePlants.location: All counties except in high elevations.

safePlants.name: Dandelion
safePlants.description: With long pointy leaves, and bright yellowish orange flowers, this planted is sought after as an addition to salads or for tea. It is Abundant in vitamin A, vitamin C, and vitamin K. As well as being known for maintaining good vision and immune function.

safePlants.name: Wood Sorrel
safePlants.description: Growing up to 10 inches tall, this heart-shaped leafleted, tiny yellow flowered, plant is a wonderful zesty treat. It is high an vitamin C and can help with nausea, fever, indigestion, and swelling.

safePlants.name: Morels
safePlants.description: This small and unique mushroom is a highly sought after ingredient for many dishes. With a hollow stem and cap, this fungi is great for it's anti-oxidative abilities, anti-inflammation, and gut health preservation. While it is edible, it must be cooked before eaten.
safePlants.location: More prevalent in high elevation counties

safePlants.name: Serviceberries
safePlants.description: The tree that these berries grow on can be found while hiking, or even around your neighborhood library. With smooth, gray bark, star-shaped white flowers,and small red berries, this sweet treat is sought after as a healthy snack or added to sweet treats. It is great to have on hand for it's notable iron amounts.

deadlyPlants.name: Pokeweed
deadlyPlants.description: 6-10 ft tall, pokeweed bushes have tiny pinkish white flowers that turn into penny sized black berries. Mashed berries stain anything a reddish/purple color. Symptoms of root consumption include: burning sensation in the mouth and throat, nausea, vomiting, a weakened pulse, drowsiness and impaired vision precede death in extreme cases.

deadlyPlants.name: Rhododendron
deadlyPlants.description: Growing up to 40 ft tall, this plant has dark green leaves, which are different shades on either side, surrounding clusters of 10-12 small white or pink flowers. Symptoms of leaf or honey consumption include hallucinations, diarrhea and death in severe cases.
deadlyPlants.location: Every county, but more prone to mountainous regions

deadlyPlants.name: Holly
deadlyPlants.description: Standing at 10-20 ft tall with small red berries matched with small and pointy dark green leaves, these bushes are perfect for the holiday season, but not for any stew. Symptoms of berry consumption include: vomiting, diarrhea, and dehydration
deadlyPlants.location: Fayette, Grant, Greenbrier, Hardy, Mercer, Monongalia, Nicholas, Pendleton, Pocahontas, Preston , Raleigh , Randolph , Summers, Tucker, and Webster.

deadlyPlants.name: Jimsonweed
deadlyPlants.description: Ranging from 3-5 ft tall with thick purple stems and large, white to purple flowers, this plant is part of the nightshade family. Symptoms of petal or nectar consumption include: rapid pulse and breathing, dilated pupils, restlessness, nervousness, muscular twitching, diarrhea, depression and weight loss. In severe cases, it is fatal.

deadlyPlants.name: Common Moonseed
deadlyPlants.description: Growing upwards of 20 ft, in a spiral fashion around trees, this vine and it's fruit are very similar to grapes. Every part of this plant is toxic and can inhibit muscle movement, as well as be fatal in severe cases.

messages.text: Anyone else see the disclaimer for the West Virginia Mushroom Club?...
did you mean to send that?

parks.name: Kanawha State Forest
parks.description: Located seven miles south of the capital city of Charleston, Kanawha State Forest is an outdoor lover's haven. It is known for its extensive network of hiking and biking trails and has some of the state's most popular picnic areas
